Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Efficient Multiline Mooring Systems for Floating Wind Turbines

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project seeks to develop a novel, integrated, and networked multiline mooring system for floating offshore wind turbines that can provide significant capital cost savings in terms of materials and installation, and thereby contribute to making offshore wind energy cost competitive with other sources. Reducing the cost of energy generated from offshore wind sources is critical to meeting national renewable energy goals and for meeting the needs of a robustly growing economy. The industry partner, Vryhof Anchors, is a world leader in anchor systems for offshore structures and has become increasingly involved in the offshore wind industry, including providing the anchoring system for the world's first floating offshore wind turbine. Vryhof, through its subsidiary Vryhof Americas, will work closely with the academic research team to ensure that research tasks are closely aligned with industrial needs, and that the academic research is informed by the latest industrial advances. Vryhof will also act as a liaison between the academic team and other industry contacts. To successfully develop the proposed multiline mooring system, the research must address issues of dynamics of floating platforms in irregular wind and wave states, mooring line actions, and the mechanics of anchor-soil interaction for a variety of anchor types, soil stratigraphies, and mooring geometry.

The principal goal of this research is to provide a path to transformation of offshore floating wind farm design from one in which turbines mooring systems are designed and constructed individually to one in which the mooring system for the entire wind farm is designed as a networked system with greatly increased material and installation efficiency. Specific research objectives are to: (1) generate idealized soil stratigraphies; (2) explore the geometric design space for wind farm layout compatible with the multiline concept; (3) develop spatially correlated wind wave models for the extent of an offshore wind farm; (4) model mooring line forces as correlated random processes; (5) analyze anchor behavior using 3D finite element analysis; (6) evaluate candidate multiline anchor designs for feasibility and cost. The project achieves broad impact through the Vryhof industrial collaboration and partnership with demonstration projects based at UMaine. Educational synergy occurs through the graduate education activities of the UMass Wind Energy IGERT program and the UMass STEM Diversity Institute and Texas A&M AGEP programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project’s main objective is to investigate a novel mooring and anchoring system for floating offshore wind turbines (FOWTs) that has potential to increase efficiency and decrease capital cost. The novel mooring and anchoring system relies on anchor sharing, where a single anchor is connected multiple mooring lines, each from a different FOWT. This is referred to as the “multiline concept” for FOWTs. The present model is comprised of farms having many FOWTs where each FOWT has three or more mooring lines and anchors to stabilize them. The proposed model of anchor sharing allows for the same number of mooring lines with fewer anchors. This could potentially reduce FOTW farm development costs by reducing the both overall number of anchors and overwater operations associated with geotechnical investigations used for anchor design and anchor installation.

The project is collaborative between three academic institutions and one industry partner: University of Massachusetts Amherst, Texas A&M University, University of Maine, and Vryhof Anchors. The goals of the project that were successfully investigated include:

  1. Investigate potential U.S. FOWT farm development sites and analyze their geology to develop example representative soil profiles with depth that include engineering properties useful for realistic design of several anchor types. Soil investigated include soft clay, stiff clay, sands, and two layered systems comprised of clay and sand.
  2. Create geometrically realistic multiline FOWT farm layouts for a range of water depths for assessment of potential increases in efficiency and economy
  3. Use available numerical simulation packages to investigate the effect wind and wave conditions on FOWT platform dynamics. Realistic wind and wave storm conditions from example sites in the U.S. are used that represent operational and extreme loading conditions. Modeling yields mooring line loads transferred to the anchors for both single and multiline FOWT geometric designs for comparison. Additionally, modeling and results are used to investigate how FOWT geometric spacing for a given wind, wave, water depth environment might affect mooring and anchor loading.
  4. Investigate the potential need for redundancy for each example FOWT farm geometry. Redundancy refers to the need to have mooring lines and anchors present in the farm that are not part of the multiline concept that allow for the FOTW linked to a single anchor farm to continue to function should one or more mooring lines or anchors “fail”.
  5. Design of realistic anchors for both single line and multiline concept geometries and evaluate differences in anchors due to the geometric differences in the mooring system. Anchors investigated include drag embedment anchors, piles, and suction caissons.
  6. Assess potential economies and efficiencies for the multiline concept, including the cost savings or increases associated with mooring line length and diameter to withstand loading and anchor size for the range of anchors investigated and anchor sizes.

Preliminary results show that for a range of FOWT farm geometries, water depths, and soil profiles studied that the multiline concepts for anchor sharing in FOWT farms is feasible under certain conditions. The research is ongoing between the full research team, and the PI is continuing to actively collaborate on research activities until the project is completed among the entire team in the coming year.

This study has significant broader impacts. They include:

  1. Opportunity investigate a novel mooring and anchoring system for floating offshore wind turbines (FOWTs) that has potential for significant development cost savings. Preliminary results show that the multiline concept is both feasible and shows promise for cost reduction, which can extend beyond offshore wind to wave, tidal, and current renewable energy technologies and aquaculture.
  2. The combined use structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, oceanography, statistics and probability, analytical modeling and numerical simulations to investigate complex floating FOWTs that are connected into a system; and
  3. Advancement of offshore engineering and renewable energy programs at three US academic institutions through research and partnership with a world-renowned offshore anchoring company for two-way knowledge sharing.
